title: Week 1: December 29–January 4 - Introduction to the Old Testament

script.speaker: David
script.text: Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. I'm David.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: And I'm Sarah.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, I want to start with something that has always puzzled me. In John 8:58, Jesus declares, 'Before Abraham was, I am,' and the Jews immediately pick up stones to kill Him. Why such a strong reaction to those words?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That's a fantastic question, David. It unlocks so much about the Old Testament. To understand their outrage, we need to go back to Exodus 3:13-15, where Moses asks God what His name is at the burning bush.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Tell me more about that moment.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: God replies, 'I AM THAT I AM,' and says, 'Thus shalt thou say unto the children of Israel, I AM hath sent me unto you.' That's the divine name—YHWH, or Jehovah. When Jesus claimed 'I am,' He was directly identifying Himself as Jehovah, the God of the Old Testament.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's profound. So the Jews recognized it as blasphemy because they saw it as Jesus equating Himself with God.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Exactly. President Dallin H. Oaks taught that scriptural records of words spoken by 'God' or the 'Lord' are almost always the words of Jehovah, our risen Lord, Jesus Christ. It's significant to realize Jesus Christ is Jehovah throughout the Old Testament.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I'm intrigued by how this changes our reading of the Old Testament. What strikes me is how many symbols point to Him right from the start.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: One powerful way to nourish ourselves in the Old Testament is to look for Jesus Christ as the Bread of Life. Take manna in Exodus 16:4, 11-15. God provides it daily, and Jesus says in John 6:35, 'I am the bread of life.'

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's a clear connection. What else stands out to you?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: The sacrificial lamb in Exodus 12:3-5 mirrors John 1:29, where John the Baptist calls Jesus 'the Lamb of God.' Then there's the brass serpent in Numbers 21:4-10, lifted up so the people could look and live, just as Jesus describes in John 3:14.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And Jonah, right? Jonah 1:4-17 and Matthew 12:38-41.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Yes, Jonah in the great fish for three days and nights foreshadows Christ's Resurrection. These symbols teach us about His role as provider, sacrifice, healer, and conqueror of death.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I hadn't connected them all like that before. It makes the Old Testament feel alive with testimony of Him.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: The Lord told Adam in Moses 6:63, 'All things have their likeness, and all things are created and made to bear record of me.' Focusing on Christ helps us find deep meaning.

script.speaker: David
script.text: How does knowing Jesus is Jehovah shift our perspective on ancient events?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Consider Exodus 6:3-5. God says to Moses, 'I appeared unto Abraham, unto Isaac, and unto Jacob, by the name of God Almighty, but by my name JEHOVAH was I not known to them.' The Joseph Smith Translation clarifies this further.

script.speaker: David
script.text: So ancient patriarchs knew Him differently?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Yes, different dispensations reveal Him progressively. Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob knew Him as God Almighty, but Moses learns the name Jehovah more fully.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's fascinating—almost like layers of understanding building over time.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: And it continues with Christ openly declaring it, then restored plainly today. What many don't realize is how the Old Testament's ancient culture, though foreign, shows familiar struggles—family joys, doubts, faith—like ours.

script.speaker: David
script.text: People like Abraham and Sarah experienced real life, yet made covenants and trusted the Savior's promise.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Precisely. The Old Testament is full of covenant stories. God seeks to make us His 'peculiar treasure' by covenant, as in Exodus 19:5.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Help me understand how covenants tie into this week's focus.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: President Russell M. Nelson's message 'The Everlasting Covenant' highlights this. It's the same covenant offered to ancient prophets like Abraham and his posterity, connecting to our temple covenants today.

script.speaker: David
script.text: So the Old Testament reveals our covenant path.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Yes, and Jeremiah 31:31-34 prophesies a new covenant written in our hearts. These patterns span dispensations.

script.speaker: David
script.text: What about the plain and precious things restored?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Nephi saw in vision that many plain and precious things were removed from the Bible, in 1 Nephi 13:21-29, 38-42. The Lord restores them through Joseph Smith—like the book of Moses and book of Abraham.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Give me an example.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Moses 7:18-19 restores Enoch's city of Zion. Abraham 3:22-28 shows the council in heaven. And Joseph Smith Translation, Genesis 14:25-40 details Melchizedek's ministry. These fill in vital truths.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's transformative. Why are they plain and precious?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: They clarify the plan of salvation, premortal life, Zion's possibility, and priesthood power—core to our covenants.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I see how ancient Israel saw Jehovah through symbols, Christ revealed Himself directly, and modern prophets restore the full picture.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Exactly. Elder Dale G. Renlund urges us to always focus on Jesus Christ, as in his message 'Jesus Christ Is the Treasure.'

script.speaker: David
script.text: What strikes me is how this applies today. How do these symbols strengthen our faith now?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: When we face uncertainty, like manna daily, we trust Christ as our sustenance. The lamb reminds us of His Atonement in our sacrifices.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And covenants give that special love and mercy from God.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Yes, as we keep them, we become His peculiar treasure. Psalm 119:105 says, 'Thy word is a lamp unto my feet, and a light unto my path.'

script.speaker: David
script.text: This really deepens my anticipation for the year.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Mine too. As we study, let's watch for how God teaches us about our covenant relationship with Him.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's a perfect invitation. Notice the brass serpent—looking to Christ heals us today, just as it did then.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Beautiful. And 2 Nephi 3:12 shows how Bible and Book of Mormon together make these truths plain.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I hadn't thought of it that way. It ties ancient and modern seamlessly.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: The plan of salvation shines through—symbols bearing record of Him across time.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, this conversation has me eager to dive deeper into the Old Testament, seeing Christ everywhere.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Me too, David. Listeners, as you begin this year, seek Him in every page, and let covenants draw you closer.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Thanks, Sarah. Until next time, keep studying.
